Analysis.name: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Although randomization was carried out by a computer system and amantadine/placebo was administered by a nurse unaware of patient assignment, no information on the presence of eventual baseline differences in demographic and/or clinical characteristics was provided.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Patients and nurses were blinded to active treatment or placebo; ITT analysis was performed.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Although the Authors state that an ITT analysis was performed, the number of missing data (according to the study flowchart) exceeds 5%; besides, there is no mention of correction for bias or sensitivity analyses. No evidence that missingness depends on its true value.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Measurement instrument was sensitive and valid; besides, comparable methods of outcome measurement between groups were used. Double-blind design, raters not aware of group allocation.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No protocol available; two outcome measurements but both reported.

Analysis.name: Change in severity of ICBs
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Although the randomization process was carried out by a computer system and allocation concealment was obtained through opaque envelopes, there are baseline differences in frequency of comorbid ICDs and history of DBS that suggest an imbalance between groups.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Even if an ITT analysis was performed, there is not enough information to support effective blinding of patients and assessors; nausea was more common in the active group and might have made blinding not effective.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Although the Authors state that an ITT analysis was performed, the number of missing data (according to the study flowchart) exceeds 5% in the active group; besides, no mention of correction for bias or sensitivity analyses. There are also more missing data in the active group, but this is likely to be related to side effects.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No evidence of poor sensitivity or poor validity of the measurement instrument used; comparable methods of outcome measurement between groups; double-blind design (raters not aware of group allocation).
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No discrepancies between the protocol and the published report; the results appear to reflect the analysis reported in the statistical section. Only one timepoint was considered; only one measurement was used.

Analysis.name: Change in frequency of ICBs
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Although the process of randomization and allocation was carried out by a central computer system and assignment was masked from the patients, study staff, investigators and data analysts, there are differences in clinical characteristics at baseline (higher QUIP-RS scores + lower rates of DA in the active group) that suggest an imbalance between groups.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Double blind design (patients and assessors not aware of group allocation); similar rates of adverse effects between active and placebo; besides, ITT analyses were performed.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Only one patient withdrew from consent, but ITT and sensitivity analyses were performed.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Measurement instrument was sensitive and valid; comparable methods of outcome measurement between groups; double-blind design.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No changes to analysis plan; only one outcome measurement and one timepoint were reported; only one analysis of the outcome measurement was reported.

Analysis.name: Change in frequency of ICBs
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: The randomization was made via random number tables, was held independently of researchers performing the initial clinical assessment and there were no significant differences in baseline demographic and clinical characteristics.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Although patients and assessors were not blinded to group allocation and no information was provided on eventual deviations from intended interventions because of the trial context, the Authors used an appropriate method of analysis (m-ITT).
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Although the number of missing data (according to the study flowchart) exceeds 5% and there is no mention of correction for bias or sensitivity analyses performed, we judged the risk of bias related to this domain as low because there were more missing data in the control group.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Even if there was no evidence of poor sensitivity or poor validity of the measurement instrument used and the Authors used comparable methods of outcome measurement between groups, the raters were aware of the group allocation and no information on the likelihood that assessment was influenced by knowledge of intervention was provided.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No discrepancies between the protocol and the published report; the results appear to reflect the analysis reported in the statistical section. Besides, only one timepoint and one measurement was considered and used.
